text.49: Then Allah SWT explained that all creatures in the heavens and on earth are subject to His power. They prostrate to Allah in their own way, according to their natural disposition (fitrah). Even the angels in the heavens do not want to be arrogant and do not disobey Allah's decrees.
text.50:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains the obedience of the angels specifically, that the angels are submissive under the power of Allah and diligently carry out what He commands. Creatures in the heavens and on earth cannot and are not able to avoid Allah's laws and provisions that apply.

Thus, this explanation is given to those who deny the existence of Allah and are always making deception, so that they realize that no creation of Allah can escape from His power. Allah says:

"Then He turned to the heaven when it was smoke, and said to it and to the earth: 'Come both of you willingly or unwillingly.' They both said: 'We come willingly.'" (Fussilat/41: 11)

And His word again:

"And to Allah prostrates whoever is within the heavens and the earth, willingly or unwillingly, and so do their shadows in the mornings and afternoons." (ar-Ra'd/13: 15)

With this explanation, it is hoped that they can end their denial and return to their original *fitrah*, which is to submit under the power of Allah and believe in the truth of the revelation that was sent down to His chosen servant, Muhammad SAW.
text.51:
Allah SWT explains to His servants that they should never worship gods other than Him, because that would mean associating partners with Allah, while Allah is Exalted above having partners. It is impossible for Allah SWT, the Almighty in this universe, to be more than one. He is One, and only He has the right to be worshipped.

Allah commands mankind to fear His threats and punishment. He also forbids mankind from associating partners with Him and creating other objects of worship besides Him. Clearly, the prohibition contained in this verse is against worshipping two gods. However, the number two does not only indicate the number two, but to indicate the smallest number. What is meant is worshipping gods other than Allah and so that it does not enter into people's minds that there are other gods besides Him.
text.52:
Allah SWT then explains that everything in the universe belongs to Him. Allah does not divide His power to others in managing everything in the heavens and on earth. He does not need helpers or partners. Therefore, He alone deserves to be obeyed. Obedience in the truest sense, sincere, and unending.

Thus, it is not right for people to be pious to other than Him because those gods do not have the power to remove existing blessings or bring punishment. Therefore, piety must be attributed only to Allah.
text.53:
Furthermore, Allah SWT explains why only Allah should be feared. This is because all the blessings they receive, such as health and happiness, are solely from Allah. Therefore, it is the duty of mankind to be grateful for His blessings and to praise His unending goodness to His creatures.

Conversely, when people are afflicted by life's difficulties, hardships, illnesses, and so on, it is to Allah that they complain and ask for help. This is the nature of humans that when they are in difficulty, they become aware of their own weakness and the existence of a power outside of themselves that controls them.
text.54:
Then Allah SWT reveals that if Allah grants their request, namely removing the hardship they suffer, they immediately turn back to associating other gods with Allah, and worshiping those idols again. They no longer want to be grateful for the blessings that Allah has given. Such is their deception.

Allah SWT says:

And when harm touches you upon the sea, those that you call upon vanish from you except Him. But when He delivers you to the land, you turn away [from Him]. And ever is man ungrateful. (al-Isra/17: 67)
text.55:
This verse states that Allah allows the disbelievers and polytheists to deny the blessings He has bestowed upon them. Allah also allows them to deny Him as the All-Powerful Being who removes the dangers that befall them, to the point of denying that Allah, the Almighty, releases them from those dangers.

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT affirms that they are allowed to enjoy worldly life and satisfy their desires until the time comes when death seizes them. After that, they will surely return to Allah. At that time, they will know with absolute certainty the consequences of their denial and disobedience. They will regret their actions with a regret that is of no use.
text.56:
Allah SWT explains that among the actions of the polytheists is providing offerings to their idols, even though these offerings are blessings from Allah bestowed upon them. The various offerings given to the idols are the products of their agriculture or their livestock. They do this with the intention that the idols can help them. However, they do not know in the slightest that the idols are not capable of providing benefit or preventing them from dangers that will befall them. This action of theirs is an act of shirk, which is to deify others besides Allah.

Allah SWT says:

"And they assign to Allah a share of what He has created of tilth and cattle, and say: "This is for Allah," according to their claim, "and this is for our partners." But that which is for their "partners" reaches not Allah, while that which is for Allah reaches their "partners"! Evil is their judgment." (al-An'am/6: 136)

Then Allah threatens them with a severe threat. Allah swears by His Name that He will indeed ask them for accountability for their actions of fabricating gods besides Allah. Then they will be punished according to their denial and their actions.

Allah SWT says:

"So, by your Lord, We will surely question them all," (al-Hijr/15: 92)

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT holds them accountable for what they fabricated, giving the understanding that Allah condemns them for the words or deeds that they fabricated.
text.57:
Then Allah swt revealed another form of their shirk, which was attributing daughters to Allah, while for themselves, they desired sons.

Allah swt says:

And they make the angels, who are servants of the Most Merciful, females. Did they witness their creation? Their testimony will be recorded, and they will be questioned. (az-Zukhruf/43: 19)

The polytheists considered the angels to be daughters of Allah. Their actions are considered a major sin, because they attributed something to Allah that is not appropriate, namely that Allah has daughters, even though they themselves are not happy to have daughters.

Allah swt says:

Is it for you the males and for Him the females? That is then an unjust division. (an-Najm/53: 21-22)

And His saying:

Indeed, it is out of their [own] invention that they say, "Allah has begotten children." And indeed, they are liars. Has He chosen daughters over sons? What is [wrong] with you? How do you judge? (as-shaffat/37: 151-154)

Allah swt affirms that He is Exalted above all their accusations. Indeed, it is very vile that they only want sons and do not want daughters.
text.58:
Furthermore, Allah swt reveals their attitude regarding daughters, which is that when they are given news that their wives have given birth to a daughter, their faces darken with annoyance and shame.

This similar feeling is caused by their own feeling that daughters only bring shame to their people, because daughters cannot help in war, and if they lose the war, daughters become spoils of war. In reality, they are punished by their own feelings because of the assumption that a woman's dignity is no more than a transferable item.
text.59:
Allah SWT further explains the behavior of the polytheists when they were blessed with a daughter. They withdrew from their community upon receiving the bad news of the birth of a daughter. They hid from the crowd for fear of being humiliated, and did not want anyone to know the shame that had befallen them. Then, it crossed their minds whether the child who brought shame would be cared for while enduring prolonged humiliation, because daughters were not entitled to inheritance or societal recognition, and were only servants to men, or whether they would bury her alive in the ground. Their habit of burying daughters alive was considered a great sin for which they would be held accountable on the Day of Reckoning, because this act contradicted human conscience and common sense.

Allah SWT says:

"And when the infant girl [who was] buried alive is asked, for what sin was she killed?" (at-Takwir/81: 8-9)

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT states how evil what they determined and concluded was, namely that they were ashamed to have a daughter, so they hid themselves from the crowd. They were so ashamed that they felt they had to choose whether to keep the daughter but endure shame, or bury her alive. Allah affirms that their view of daughters was very wrong.
text.60: Allah SWT explains that the bad fate is actually possessed by the disbelievers, namely they will be humiliated because they are put into hell. Meanwhile, Allah will remain glorious, not needing a child or anyone else in creating and managing this universe. Even if all humans in this universe rebel against Him, it will not damage His glory and omnipotence. It is humanity itself that loses in this world because it does not enjoy the benefits obtained from the implementation of the noble values that He taught, and in the hereafter, they enter hell. That is what Allah affirms at the end of this verse, that He is All-Powerful in His omnipotence and All-Wise in inflicting punishment on those who deny. Meaning, the punishment is indeed something that is fitting for those who deny.
text.61: Allah SWT threatens the polytheists who are steeped in sin. The threat is that if Allah wants to punish mankind for their injustice, He is able to do so. They will be wiped out from the face of the earth, with not a single one remaining. However, Allah does not desire that. Because of His vast mercy, Allah postpones His punishment until a predetermined time, which is when death has taken them. The intention is so that they can change their views and behavior. However, if they still do not change, Allah will send down punishment when their death comes. And when that death has come, they will not be able to postpone or hasten it for even a moment. Then in the afterlife, they will be cast into hell.
text.62:
Once again, Allah explains that they always attribute everything they dislike to Allah, including daughters. They do not want to have daughters, because according to them, daughters are only for Allah. So, Allah is the one who is humiliated.

It is also explained that they always utter false words, namely that they will always be happy both in this world and in the hereafter, even though they are steeped in sin. This is refuted by Allah, saying that their place is hell and they will be forcibly thrown into it.

From the information above, it is clear that they truly do not want to believe in the Day of Resurrection and do not want to realize their evil deeds. That is why Allah SWT emphasizes that they will undoubtedly be inhabitants of hell and will feel a very painful torment at the appointed time, namely the Day of Judgment (akhirat).
text.63: In this verse, Allah SWT swears by His own name that He has indeed sent many messengers to the nations before Prophet Muhammad. Those messengers invited them to believe in and worship Allah SWT. However, those nations were deceived by the trickery of Satan, so they thought their deeds were good, when in reality they were evil deeds. Satan is ultimately their companion, and will accompany them into Hell.
text.64:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains the function of the Qur'an, which is as a foundation and guide that can open their minds to be able to assess the truth of divine guidance. Allah SWT explains that He sent down the Book to the Prophet Muhammad SAW to be a guide for his people. Also, so that the Prophet SAW can explain the issues they doubt or disbelieve, so that they can see what is right and what is wrong, what is true and what is false.

In addition, the Qur'an functions as a guide that can lead its people to the truth so that they avoid error. The Qur'an also functions as Allah's greatest mercy to servants who are willing to believe. By taking guidance from the Qur'an, they will be guided in life in this world and will be happy in this world and in the hereafter.
text.65:
Allah SWT invites His servants to pay attention to the evidence and proofs that demonstrate the truth that Allah SWT is One and He alone deserves to be Lord and worthy of worship. In this regard, Allah explains that He is the One who sends down rain from the sky, which is needed by various kinds of plants on the earth's surface. If there were no rain, the earth would certainly be dry, barren, and impossible to be grown with plants and grasses.

This shows that Allah has the power to revive the land and fertilize it after there are no signs of life. Those who pay attention to this event will certainly see clear evidence and a definite sign of the existence of Allah the Almighty. This can only be understood by those who are willing to listen to Allah's explanation, pay attention to and think about the signs of His Oneness. This can sometimes be done through direct research or by listening to and understanding the experiences or research results of others as well as possible.
text.66:
Furthermore, Allah swt calls upon the attention of His servants to observe livestock, for indeed there is a valuable lesson in livestock, namely that Allah separates milk from blood and excrement. Livestock eat grass, and from that food, blood and excrement are produced. From between the two, Allah produces milk that is pure and nutritious. This shows that Allah is All-Powerful and His Mercy is vast for His servants.

Scientifically, it can be explained that in the mammary glands of mammals there is a gland that functions to produce milk. Through veins or arteries, these glands receive a supply of substances formed from blood and substances from digested food extracts (chyle). These two components cannot be consumed directly. The mammary gland will process these two components with existing enzymes, and produce milk that can be consumed directly. The milk produced has a color and aroma that are completely different from the original substances.

Breast milk (ASI) has the right components to meet the nutritional needs of infants and protection against possible diseases. The balance of nutrients contained in breast milk is ideal for the body of a very young baby. At the same time, breast milk also contains nutrients that stimulate brain and nervous system development. Artificial baby milk made based on today's high technology cannot replace this one baby food.

Another anti-infection element is that breast milk provides a good environment for the growth of "good" bacteria, called "normal flora." The role of these bacteria is to protect against bacteria, viruses and disease-causing parasites. Furthermore, breast milk also regulates the occurrence of the immune system (body immunity) against various infectious diseases. Thus is the scientific explanation.
text.67:
Furthermore, Allah swt asks His servants to pay attention to dates and grapes. From these two fruits, humans can produce *sakar*, which is an intoxicating drink that is forbidden, and good drinks that are permissible. A narration from Ibn 'Abbas explains, " *Sakar* is an intoxicating drink that is forbidden, derived from dates and grapes. Good sustenance is halal food that can be produced from dates and grapes."

So from dates and grapes, humans can produce various types of food. Among them are those that are harmful and those that are beneficial. That which is harmful is prohibited by religion, while that which is beneficial is permitted to be produced. Thus, this verse already contains an indication for those of pure thought that drinking alcoholic beverages is *haram* (forbidden) and should not be produced.

At the end of the verse, Allah swt affirms that in the creation of these two kinds of plants, there are clear signs to demonstrate the Oneness of God for those who use their minds to research, observe, and learn from the creation of the plants mentioned in the verse.
text.68:
Then Allah SWT draws the attention of His servants to observe bees. Allah has given bees the instinct to have the skill to build nests in hills, on trees, and in buildings erected by humans. Someone who pays attention to how skilled bees are in making their nests will certainly be amazed. Bee nests are made of a wax-like material and have a hexagonal shape linked together, which, according to building structure experts, is the space that contains the most content compared to other shapes. When considering its weight, the bee nest is very light, but it can withstand a heavy load, namely honey, eggs, and embryos. This is also evidence that demonstrates the power of Allah the One and Only.

The verse above describes the life of honeybees briefly but accurately as follows.

1. "...Make nests in some of the mountains and some of the trees, and in some of the high places that they build...". Bee groups are estimated to consist of at least 20,000 species. Each type has its own way of making its nest. They use all means, from caves located in the mountains, holes in old trees, or making their own nests and hanging them on tree branches. Considering that this verse is specifically addressed to honeybees, a more detailed description of honeybee nests will be provided.

Honeybee nests, or bee nests in general, are strategic and central places for the entire life of the group. From the place to nurture offspring (larvae) to the information center, everything is in the nest.

Honeybee nests consist of chambers in the form of almost perfect hexagonal holes. Construction experts acknowledge that the hexagonal shape is the strongest shape, saving materials and space. This shape also prevents other insects from entering the gaps between the chambers and making nests.

2. "...Then eat from every fruit..." The main ingredient used as food for honeybees is nectar, a sweet liquid found in flowers. Meanwhile, other types of bees also obtain food from fruit juices.

3. "...And follow the ways of your Lord in ease...." In the process of searching for flower fields, several worker bees are sent as guides to find potential areas. They can fly up to five kilometers and will continue searching until they find a sufficient amount to harvest, which is then conveyed to other bees.

"Allah revealed to the bee" contains a figurative meaning. Why can revelation, which is usually revealed to humans, be revealed to bees? We must understand this verse by understanding what the function and purpose of Allah revealing revelation is. Revelation aims to provide guidance. So Allah gives guidance to the bee nation to be obeyed throughout their lives by every bee until the Day of Judgment. Unlike humans, where some are obedient and some are disobedient, and even those who deny the revelation from Allah SWT. Bees (and other animals and plants) without exception will obey and make it their guide and guide in life.

In this verse, Allah's guidance is to make (bee) nests in places made by humans. This means that Allah helps humans to cultivate and utilize them as explained in An-Naá¸¥l 16:69. Many benefits can be obtained from the plant world, and some of them are very useful after being further processed by animals, for example, honey obtained from the activities of honeybees.

Aristotle was the first person to study and learn about honeybees. Although many of his theories do not make sense when studied with current knowledge, it must be acknowledged that he was a pioneer in researching and revealing the life of bees. Human attention is estimated to have started between 8,000 and 15,000 years ago. Many paintings on prehistoric cave walls show how humans harvest honey from honeybee nests. Beekeeping is thought to have started in Egypt around 2400 BC.
text.69:
Allah then calls upon His servants to consider how He has given skill to the bees to gather food from various kinds of flowers and transform it into honey that is long-lasting and nutritious. This skill is inherited by bees from generation to generation.

Bees suck food from flowers, which then enters their stomachs, and from their stomachs comes honey of various colors. Some are white, some are yellowish, and some are reddish, according to the type of bee and the flowers in the surrounding area.

Among the benefits of honey is for body endurance and perhaps also as a medicine for various diseases. This can be accepted by science, among other things because honey is easily digested and contains various kinds of vitamins.

The explanation about the function of honey can be read in a hadith:

That a person came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said, "Indeed, my brother has a stomach ache." So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Give him honey to drink." Then the man gave him honey. Then the man came again to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said, "O Messenger of Allah, I have given him honey, but his stomach ache has worsened." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Go and give him honey to drink (again)." So the man went and gave him honey again, then the man came again to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said, "O Messenger of Allah, his stomach ache has only worsened." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Allah is truthful and your brother's stomach is lying. Go and give your brother honey again." Then the man went and gave him honey again, and he was cured. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri)

And the hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him):

The cure is in three things: cupping, drinking honey, and cauterizing with fire (hot iron), and I forbid my ummah from cauterizing. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Abbas)

Some of the benefits provided by bees are as follows:

1. Their honey is a delicious drink that is beneficial for health. Their nests can be made into candles, materials for batik, and so on.

2. Bees help pollinate flowers so that fertilization occurs.
text.70:
Allah SWT explains that He is the One who created mankind and determined their lifespan. Among humans, there are those who die while still in the womb, some die at birth, some die in childhood, some die when they reach the peak of their glory, and some die after reaching a very old age, after becoming weak and senile.

Allah SWT says:

"And whomever We grant long life We reverse him in creation. Then will they not understand?" (Yasin/36: 68)

Most people desire a long life, but remain healthy, and do not want to become senile. In a hadith of the Prophet SAW it is mentioned:

That the Messenger of Allah SAW said in his prayer, "I seek refuge in You, O Allah, from miserliness, laziness, extreme old age (senility), the torment of the grave, the trials (fitnah) of the Dajjal, and the trials (fitnah) in life and in death." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Anas bin Malik)

When humans are given a long life, their physical strength gradually decreases until they reach a point where they are as if returned to childhood again. They become weak, senile, and can no longer remember what they once knew.

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT affirms that He is All-Knowing of everything. This means that He knows the wisdom behind the creation of mankind and the wisdom behind their death. Allah is also All-Powerful to cause humans to die while still infants or after old age.
text.71:
After Allah explained the differences in human ages in this verse, He mentions the differences in their sustenance. Allah swt explains that Allah favors some people's sustenance over others. Some people are rich, while others are poor; some people control sources of sustenance, and others do not obtain sufficient sustenance for their lives. All of this is so that they can help each other because they need each other.

Then Allah swt explains that among those who are given more sustenance, there are those who are unwilling to give even a little of their sustenance to those who work for them, who should receive a portion from them. Even though between those who control and those who are controlled, between masters and slaves, both have the same right to that sustenance. Therefore, it is fitting that the sustenance be distributed fairly and evenly to all parties. If the owner of capital feels entitled to profit because of the capital they possess, workers should be given income according to their abilities, so that both the owner of capital and the workers can enjoy the sources of income.

Allah swt says:

He sets forth for you a parable from yourselves: Do you have among those whom your right hands possess partners in what We have provided you so that you are equal therein, fearing them as you fear each other? Thus do We explain the signs for a people who understand. (ar-Rum/30: 28)

At the end of the verse, Allah reminds that all of that is His favor. Therefore, they should be grateful for that favor by not monopolizing the sources of income for the benefit of a particular group or faction.
text.72:
Then Allah explains His blessings, namely that Allah SWT has created spouses for them from their own kind. These spouses are partners in cooperation to build families and communities. With these spouses, humans can have offspring to maintain and develop the human race in carrying out their duties as caliphs on this earth. Furthermore, Allah explains that He has given them sustenance in the form of good and useful food and drink. Therefore, humans should not be afraid of the difficulty of obtaining sustenance because of children. On the contrary, they must educate these children so that they will be able to carry out their duties as caliphs on earth when they grow up.

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT rebukes the disbelievers who believe in idols as gods, even though these idols cannot do anything. Meanwhile, they deny Allah's blessings as if sustenance is not from Allah.
text.73: Furthermore, Allah swt explains that the polytheists worship idols or other gods besides Allah, even though their gods are unable to provide them with sustenance from the sky, such as sending down rain, growing plants, and so on. These idols have no power whatsoever because they are inanimate objects. Idols cannot possibly provide any benefit, and even if destroyed, they cannot do anything.
text.74:
Allah forbids His servants from equating Allah's attributes with those of His creation, because Allah's attributes are incomparable and unmatched. To strengthen the understanding of this verse, a narration from Ibn Mundhir and Abi Hatim from Ibn 'Abbas can be presented, in which he said regarding the meaning of the verse that Allah said, "Therefore, do not assume the existence of other gods besides Me, because indeed there is no god but Me."

Then Allah SWT affirms that Allah is All-Knowing of everything in the heavens and on earth. He knows the evil deeds committed by His creation, and He is the One who has the power to punish them with a painful torment. They do not know even a little of what torment they will have to endure.
text.75:
In this verse, Allah swt makes a parable about the polytheists regarding their belief that equates their objects of worship, in the form of statues and idols, with Allah, the Most Perfect.

The error and falsehood of their belief is similar to the error of those who equate a slave who has no rights or power with a free person, who has the right to own, develop, and spend wealth according to their wishes, whether secretly or openly.

Everyone can easily see that the two are vastly different, in terms of nobility, power, or grandeur. Similarly, are the polytheists. They make inanimate objects the foundation and goal when offering prayers and placing hopes. How far astray they are in equating the Creator of the universe with creatures who have limitations.

All praise belongs only to Allah swt. He is the most deserving of receiving all kinds of praise because He is the Great and Perfect. All praiseworthy attributes are gathered in Him. All praise is directed only to Him, not to statues, idols, or anything else. Objects of worship other than Allah, none are worthy of receiving praise. However, many people do not know or realize that all attributes of perfection belong only to Allah swt. Because of ignorance, they see attributes of perfection also existing in things other than Allah. They make that creation the object of adoration or worship.
text.76:
As with the previous verse, in this verse Allah swt explains again the parable for the polytheists in a clearer form regarding their belief in their idol deities. Allah swt takes the parable of two people: one who is mute, foolish, and does not understand anything, and another who is able to speak and is capable. The first person is a parable for the idol deities of the polytheists, while the second is a parable for Allah. Is it fitting to equate the two? If such a thing is not fitting, then it is even more unfitting to equate idols with Allah.

Allah swt in this verse explains the similarity of characteristics between idols and a mute person who not only lacks the ability to speak, but also lacks the ability to think. He does not understand the intentions of others, and others also cannot understand his intentions. Therefore, he cannot resolve his own affairs, let alone the affairs of others. He is only a burden to others, wherever he is placed, and any task given to him will certainly not bring good results.

The attribute of Allah "enjoining justice or truth" contains the understanding that He knows, teaches, and loves justice and truth and commands His servants to be just. Allah loves those who do justice and are just and does not command His servants except to uphold justice. Indeed, Allah swt is Most Holy from attributes that are contrary to justice such as being unjust, oppressive, ignorant, and miserly. His commands and laws are entirely just. Those who are just in character and deed are the beloved and guardians of Allah. They live in the presence of Allah and under His light.

The attribute of Allah swt "on a straight path" contains the understanding that Allah does not command anything other than truth and justice. Allah does not create or bring into existence anything except for benefit, mercy, wisdom, and justice. Allah is always upon the truth in His words and deeds.

Allah does not inflict punishment unjustly upon His servants, does not torture without a sin committed by that servant, nor does He reduce even a little of the good deeds he has done, and does not burden a person with the sin of another. The actions and deeds of Allah are always full of wisdom and end with goodness. All of this is because Allah always wants His servants to be in a state of righteousness.
text.77:
In this verse, Allah SWT affirms the perfection of His knowledge of the unseen and His omnipotence. Among the unseen are all things beyond the reach of human senses and intellect, whether in the heavens or on earth. Only Allah SWT knows about what exists beyond this visible realm.

Although humankind's knowledge of outer space and the state of the earth is very advanced today, what they do not yet know is far greater. When humans reached the moon, the mysteries and secrets of the planets Mars, Venus, and others still stretched before them. Yet, these planets are like grains of sand in the middle of a vast desert when compared to the vastness of the universe.

Similarly, regarding the state of this earth. No geologist can accurately predict when an earthquake will occur or a volcano will erupt. Even within humans themselves, there are still things that are mysteries or secrets of Allah that humans have not yet discovered, even though for centuries experts in their respective fields have tried to think about and reveal them. No one can be sure what they will experience tomorrow, when death will come to them, and where they will be buried. All of that is unseen for humans. Nevertheless, this ignorance is a great blessing from Allah for humans. They can make plans and actions according to their desires.

The Day of Judgment is also included in the unseen. Allah SWT specifically mentions the Day of Judgment because this issue has received much rejection and rebuttal in every era and every nation. Many people even deny it, and declare it as something impossible to happen.

Allah keeps the time of the Day of Judgment a secret so that humans do not stop their life activities. Humans should not need to think about when the Day of Judgment will occur, because that is Allah's business. What is important for them is to live life according to the guidelines that have been established by Allah SWT.

The issue of the Day of Judgment is very easy for Allah SWT. The speed of the event is as fast as the blink of an eye or even faster. This speed is according to the time that can be described by human calculation because Allah's arrangement of the universe cannot actually be connected with space and time. Easy or difficult, and fast or slow are human measures. Allah is indeed All-Powerful over all things. When Allah wills something, He says, "Kun (Be)," and that thing is created. Nothing can hinder His will.
text.78:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the unseen and the wonders that are very close to humans. They know the phases of fetal growth, but they do not know how the process of fetal development occurs in the womb until it reaches perfection. From the meeting of sperm and egg cells to becoming a new human being carrying the traits of both parents and ancestors. In this process of creation, there are hidden secrets of life.

After reaching perfection, Allah brings humans out of their mother's womb in a state of knowing nothing. But while still in the womb, Allah bestows potential, talents, and abilities such as thinking, feeling happy, sensing, and so on upon humans. After humans are born, with Allah's guidance, all that potential and talent develops. Their minds can think about good and evil, right and wrong, and truth and falsehood. With developed hearing and sight, humans recognize the world around them, maintain their lives, and establish relationships with fellow humans. Through reason and the senses, human experience and knowledge increase and develop from day to day. All of this is God's infinite grace and gift to humans. Therefore, they should be grateful to Him, both by believing in the oneness of Allah and not associating partners with Him, and by using all of Allah's blessings to worship and obey Him.

Hadith of the Prophet Muhammad saw:

From Abu Hurairah r.a., he said, "The Messenger of Allah said, "Indeed, Allah swt says, "Whoever antagonizes My beloved, then I declare war against him. And My servant does not draw near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than performing what I have obligated upon him. My servant continues to draw near to Me by performing voluntary acts of worship until I love him. When I love him, I become his hearing with which he hears, his sight with which he sees, his hand with which he strikes, and his foot with which he walks. If he asks Me, I will surely grant him his request, and if he seeks refuge in Me, I will surely protect him." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)
text.79:
Another miracle witnessed daily by humans is presented by Allah in this verse to demonstrate His power. The beauty of the scenery when birds fly in the air, soaring, and sometimes seeming to float, played by the wind, is a very impressive sight for those who believe in the greatness and majesty of Allah.

The heart of a believer is like the heart of a poet. He is always fascinated by the beauty of creation and its events. That beauty stirs the feelings and touches the conscience. A believer expresses his feelings towards the beauty of nature with faith, worship, and uttering tasbih to God. If a believer has a talent for writing/broadcasting, then he will express his feelings with beautiful language or compositions about the beauty and greatness of nature and its Creator. This cannot be expressed by a poet whose heart has never been touched by the sweetness of faith.

A believer can see signs of God's power and greatness, such as the ease with which a bird flies in the air. That a bird can fly is a miracle. To be able to fly and take off, a bird should be very light. However, at the same time, it must also be very strong and resilient. Strength is needed to be able to stay in flight for a long time, and to maneuver to catch prey or when descending to their perches.

To make its body light, the bones of birds are generally hollow in the middle and have thin walls. The weight of the bird's body is placed in the middle of the body. In the chest there is a large sternum attached to the large pectoral muscles. It is these pectoral muscles that move the wings. The pectoral muscles comprise about 25-30% of the total body weight of the bird.

The most important thing for a bird to be able to fly is the presence of wing organs and feathers. The wing is a kind of hand that has a large and strong ball joint at the shoulder. This joint is very special, and is used for very complex mobility. Its use is so that the bird can maneuver well in the air.

Wing feathers are a very beautiful creation of God. Light, yet strong, flexible, versatile, easy to maintain, functioning as heat insulators, waterproof, and replaceable. Feather color is very important for birds. Some birds have colors that match their environment, which functions as camouflage. Other types use their colors to attract the opposite sex.
text.80:
This verse explains the blessings bestowed by Allah upon mankind to serve as signs of His Oneness, such as Allah granting houses to mankind. These houses not only function as dwellings or shelters from rain and heat, but also as places to create an atmosphere of safety, peace, and tranquility, as well as to foster affection and loyalty among their inhabitants. From good households, good people are born. The Islamic religion establishes rules to guarantee the sanctity of the home as a place of residence. A person is forbidden from entering another person's house before giving greetings and seeking permission from its inhabitants, even if he is a state official. It is not permissible for someone to inspect another person's house for any reason, and it is not permissible to spy on its inhabitants, causing a sense of insecurity for the family residing in that house.

That is the understanding of a house and its function for humans who reside in one place. To nomadic peoples, Allah SWT bestows upon them the blessing of animal hides for the purpose of shelter. They build tents and huts from the hides and wool of these livestock while wandering in the desert, herding their animals. These items are easy and light to carry from one place to another.

Another blessing of Allah to mankind is the wool and hides of livestock, which can be used for clothing, household utensils, and other things. Sheep's wool, camel hides, and goat hides are goods that they have been able to trade from ancient times until now. From this verse, a legal argument can be derived that the hides and wool from livestock that are halal to eat are pure.
text.81:
In this verse, Allah swt mentions His blessings in addition to the blessings already mentioned, which provide a sense of security, peace, and tranquility. To nations that are settled or advanced, Allah bestows the blessing of shelter such as houses, hotels, and buildings, which are generally made of wood, iron, stone, and other materials. Allah provides materials from the mountains, such as stone and sand, to build buildings, fortresses, or protective dwellings in the mountains. All of this creates a sense of security and peace in the souls of its inhabitants. Allah swt provides them with clothing made of sheep's wool or cotton that protects them from heat and cold, as well as clothing made of iron to protect their bodies from sharp weapons during warfare.

Such are the blessings that Allah bestows upon mankind. Allah will perfect the worldly blessings upon the Muslims by granting them power and dominion, and by establishing the purpose of their struggle to seek the pleasure of Allah and to establish benefit for mankind. Therefore, they should realize all the great blessings from Allah and also acknowledge their obligation to the Giver of blessings, to then believe in Him, abandon other objects of worship, and perform righteous deeds.

Allah says:

And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference. (al-Isra'/17: 70)

(82) After Allah explained His blessings and favors to mankind, in this verse Allah affirms to the Messenger saw that if the disbelievers continue to turn away from the teachings of the Messenger and reject all explanations and elaborations of the proofs of the truth of the religion conveyed to them, this should not sadden him or cause despair in his soul. The Messenger's duty is only to convey, and he has fulfilled it perfectly, namely conveying and explaining the Islamic religious law, its ideals, and the wisdoms contained within that law. Cultivating faith in the souls of people or making people believers is actually beyond the ability of the Messenger saw.
text.82:
In this verse, Allah SWT mentions His blessings in addition to the blessings already mentioned, which provide a sense of security, peace, and tranquility. To nations that are settled or advanced, Allah bestows the blessing of shelter such as houses, hotels, and buildings that are generally made of wood, iron, stone, and so on. Allah provides materials from the mountains such as stone and sand to build buildings, fortresses, or protective dwellings in the mountains. All of this creates a sense of security and tranquility in the souls of its inhabitants. Allah SWT provides them with clothing made of sheep's wool or cotton that protects them from heat and cold, as well as clothing made of iron to protect their bodies from sharp weapons during warfare.

Such are the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon mankind. Allah will perfect the worldly blessings upon the Muslims by granting them power and dominion, and establishing the purpose of their struggle to seek Allah's pleasure and establish the benefit of mankind. Therefore, they should realize all the great blessings from Allah and also acknowledge the obligation towards the Giver of blessings, to then believe in Him, abandon other objects of worship, and perform righteous deeds.

Allah says:

And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference. (al-Isra'/17: 70)
text.83: In this verse, Allah explains the arrogance and haughtiness of most people. They know clearly that things like stone, wood, iron, and other materials that become the building materials for their shelters, and cotton, wool, sheep's wool, and other animal skins that become materials for clothing and their daily needs, are blessings that come from Allah SWT, not from their objects of worship besides Allah, and not even from the work of their own hands. Nevertheless, they deny that these blessings are from Allah SWT, so they feel no need to be grateful, offer prayers, worship, and devote themselves to the Lord, the Creator and Giver of these blessings. They consider these blessings to be thanks to statues and objects of worship besides Allah, or they consider them to be merely gifts of the universe, which exist on their own. Indeed, most people are disbelievers who oppose and deny the revelation conveyed by the Messenger. They do not want to believe in it even though they know the truth of the religion he brought, because of their arrogance and haughtiness.
text.84:
Allah SWT explains that on the Day of Judgment, the messengers will be witnesses over their respective communities. They are the ones who know the attitude of their people when they preached, whether their people accepted the invitations and calls conveyed, or whether they disbelieved and rejected them. The testimony of the messengers regarding the acceptance and rejection of their people is accompanied by sufficient explanations and true evidence. Based on this testimony, punishment is imposed upon them. They are not given the opportunity to present reasons to defend themselves or to apologize for all their deeds and actions during their lifetime in the world.

Allah says:

"This is the Day when they will not speak, And they will not be permitted to make an excuse." (al-Mursalat/77: 35-36)

And Allah says:

"And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you. And We did not make the qiblah which you used to face except that We might make evident who would follow the Messenger from who would turn back on his heels. And indeed, it is difficult except for those whom Allah has guided. And never would Allah have caused you to lose your faith. Indeed Allah is, to the people, Kind and Merciful." (al-Baqarah/2: 143)

And His saying:

"(Remember) the Day We will call forth every people with their record [of deeds]. Then whoever is given his record in his right hand - those will read their records, and injustice will not be done to them, [even] as much as a thread [in the date seed]." (al-Isra'/17: 71)

The Hereafter is the day of recompense for deeds in the world and not a time to repent and do good deeds to atone for sins. On the Day of Judgment, humans only receive decisions from Allah, who makes decisions with the utmost justice, entering Paradise or entering Hell.

Allah says:

"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-8)
text.85:
This verse explains the punishment for the wrongdoers, namely the polytheists who deny the messengers and are hostile to them, as was the case with the polytheists of Mecca. When witnessing the punishment that would be inflicted upon them, they tried to defend themselves to alleviate the torment. However, their defense was not accepted because there was no valid reason to present to reduce their punishment. The time for repentance had passed, and the Day of Judgment is the day of judgment. Every human being is brought before the court of God, the All-Wise and All-Knowing. Everyone in the court must speak truthfully and honestly, whether they are a witness or an accused. If the witness has spoken truthfully with true evidence, then the accused must also speak truthfully and honestly, so that the judge can determine the correct punishment. It is not right for the judge to aggravate or mitigate the punishment, nor is it right for him to delay it. Similarly, the disbelievers on the Day of Judgment. Because their sins are clear, the punishment will be immediately inflicted upon them, neither lightened nor postponed. Sinners who commit injustice, commit great crimes, and oppose the religion brought by the prophets will not be able to escape the torment of hell.

Allah says:

And the criminals will see the Fire and will be certain that they are to fall therein. And they will not find from it a way to escape. (al-Kahf/18: 53)
text.86:
In this verse, it is mentioned that when those who associate partners with Allah swt see their objects of worship on the Day of Judgment, they will say to Allah, accusing those objects of worship, "These are our partners whom we used to invoke besides You." They point to those objects of worship to shift the sins they bear onto them. They think that by doing so, they can avoid or lessen the punishment of Hellfire.

In reality, they already know for certain that they will be thrown into Hellfire, but it is human nature to still seek ways to free themselves from that destruction. Their situation is like a person about to drown, who will grab anything within reach to save themselves. When they try to shift the suffering onto their objects of worship, those objects of worship immediately hurl accusations that they are truly liars. The polytheists worship others besides Allah swt out of their own awareness and will, not because of orders from those objects of worship.

As in the word of Allah:

"And they have taken besides Allah gods that they might be for them [a source of] strength." No! Those [gods] will deny their worship of them and will be against them adversaries. (Maryam/19: 81-82)
text.87:
Then Allah swt in this verse explains that those who worship objects of worship other than Allah swt will submit themselves to Allah swt on the Day of Judgment as a sign of regret.

In another verse, Allah swt says:

And if you could but see when the criminals are hanging their heads before their Lord, [saying], "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us [to the world]; we will work righteousness. Indeed, we are [now] certain." (as-Sajdah/32: 12)

The polytheists will eventually believe in their error and regret themselves. All their objects of worship will seem to vanish without a trace. Whereas in the past, they considered those objects of worship to be partners of God who could give them help.

Before declaring their submission to Allah swt, the polytheists will first deny that they have associated partners with Him, as explained by Allah swt:

On the Day when Allah will resurrect them all, and they will swear to Him as they swear to you, and they think that they are [standing] on something [good]. Unquestionably, it is they who are the liars. (al-Mujadalah/58: 18)

On the Day of Judgment, the polytheists will first deny and then submit to Allah swt. This denial is caused by the thickness of the rust of polytheism that covers their souls, making them far from the light of faith. The human nature that tends towards the recognition of the Oneness of God is covered by the darkness of the veil of shirk, so that the light of human nature is powerless to penetrate it. But then, after going through development and a long time, the rust covering the human soul thins out, while the light of human nature, which continues to live, tries to penetrate those walls, so that it finally returns to acknowledging the Oneness of Allah and surrenders to Him.

Thus is the development of the souls of the polytheists, from denial of the Oneness of God to recognition of His Oneness. However, this recognition is too late, so it is no longer beneficial to them.
text.88:
After mentioning the punishment for those who are astray, in this verse, Allah swt explains the punishment for those who are astray and lead others astray. They are the disbelievers who oppose the prophethood and messengership of Muhammad saw and deny the Qur'an. In addition, they deliberately hinder others who want to enter the religion of Islam and want to believe in Allah and His Messenger. Allah inflicts a greater punishment on them than the punishment of those who are only astray, because they are not only disbelievers, but also lead others to disbelief or prevent others from believing. So, they commit two kinds of sins: the sin caused by disbelief and the sin of misleading others, as Allah swt says:

And they prevent (others) from listening to it (the Qur'an) and they themselves stay away from it, and they destroy none but themselves, while they do not perceive. (al-An'am/6: 26)

Therefore, the punishment inflicted on them is also of two kinds: punishment for their own disbelief and punishment for their actions of misleading others. In this verse, there is evidence that shows that the punishment for disbelievers varies, just as the positions of believers in Paradise vary.
text.89:
In this verse, Allah swt explains again what will happen on the Day of Judgment to every people, namely the presence of a prophet from among themselves, who will be a witness to their deeds.

Prophet Muhammad saw will also be a witness over his people. On that final day, he will explain the attitude of his people towards the message he brought, whether they believed and obeyed his call, or whether they opposed and denied him. The prophets are the most worthy to answer all the excuses of their people.

When giving testimony, the messengers will certainly base it on their own experience or from the information of Allah swt because they no longer know what happened to their people after their death.

The Messenger of Allah shed tears when his companion, 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud, read a verse similar in meaning to the verse above:

And how will it be when We bring from every nation a witness and We bring you, [O Muhammad], against these [as a witness]? (an-Nisa'/4: 41)

'Abdullah bin Mas'ud stopped reading when he reached this verse, because the Messenger saw said to him, "Enough." 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud then turned to the Messenger saw, and saw him shedding tears.

Being a witness on the Day of Judgment is a noble position, but a heavy one. The Messenger saw will explain to Allah on the Day of Judgment the condition of his people to what extent they practice the guidance of the Qur'an that was revealed to him. On that day, there is no more excuse for the people not to be held accountable for their deeds in the world, because the Qur'an has explained to them everything, good or bad, halal and haram, and right and wrong. The Qur'an provides guidance for mankind as to which path is straight and which is astray, and which direction brings happiness and which brings misery.

Whoever affirms the Qur'an and practices all the guidance contained therein, will surely obtain mercy in this life and the hereafter. The Qur'an gives good news to those who are obedient and repent to Allah with a great reward in the hereafter and high honor for them.

The Messenger saw who was given the task of conveying the Qur'an, will later be held accountable for his duties and obligations on the Day of Judgment, as Allah says:

Then We will surely question those to whom [a message] was sent, and We will surely question the messengers. (al-A'raf/7: 6)

Among the duties of the Messenger of Allah is to explain the Qur'an to people about religious matters because some verses of the Qur'an are detailed and some are general in content. The Messenger of Allah explained the verses of Allah that are still general in nature.

The word of Allah swt:

And We have revealed to you the Reminder (Adz-dzikr - the Qur'an) that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them and that they might give thought. (an-Nahl/16: 44)

In addition to explaining verses that are still general in nature, the Messenger of Allah also established guidance and laws relating to religious and moral matters.
text.90:
Allah SWT commands Muslims to be just in all aspects of life, to implement the commands of the Qur'an, and to do *ihsan* (excellence). Justice means realizing equality and balance between rights and obligations. Fundamental rights should not be diminished due to obligations. This verse is very broad in its meaning. Ibn Mas'ud said:

And the verse with the broadest scope in the Qur'an regarding good and evil is the verse in Surah An-Nahl (which means): "Indeed, Allah orders justice and good conduct." (Narrated by Bukhari from Ibn Mas'ud in the book *al-Adab al-Mufrad*)

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir from Ikrimah that the Prophet Muhammad SAW recited this verse to al-Walid. "Repeat it, my brother," said al-Walid, so the Messenger SAW repeated the verse. Then al-Walid said, "By Allah, this Qur'an truly possesses sweetness and beauty; its top bears fruit, its bottom has roots, and it is not the words of man."

Imam Ahmad narrated that there was a companion who was initially displeased with the Messenger SAW. When this verse was recited to him by the Messenger SAW, the faith in his soul became firm, and he became fond of the Prophet SAW.

In this verse, three commands and three prohibitions are mentioned. The three commands are to be just, to do good (*ihsan*), and to be good to relatives. The three prohibitions are to commit indecency, evil, and hostility.

Injustice is the opposite of justice, so it must be avoided. Everyone's rights must be given as they should be. Happiness is only felt by humans when their rights are guaranteed in society, everyone's rights are respected, and the strong protect the weak. Deviation from justice is a deviation from Allah's *sunnah* in creating this universe. This will certainly cause chaos and upheaval in society, such as the breaking of bonds of love between humans and the planting of resentment, hatred, envy, jealousy, and so on in human hearts.

All of that will lead to enmity, which causes destruction. Therefore, Islam establishes the foundations of justice to preserve the continuity of society. In the Qur'an, many verses were revealed in Mecca and Medina, commanding people to be just and forbidding injustice. Among them are:

Allah SWT's saying:

"O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm for Allah, witnesses in justice, and do not let the hatred of a people prevent you from being just. Be just; that is nearer to righteousness. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is Acquainted with what you do." (al-Ma'idah/5: 8)

Allah SWT establishes justice as a general foundation for the life of society for every nation in every age. Justice is the purpose of sending messengers to the world and the purpose of the *sharia* and laws revealed to them.

Allah SWT's saying:

"We have already sent Our messengers with clear evidences and sent down with them the Scripture and balance that the people may maintain [their affairs] with justice. And We sent down iron, wherein is great military might and benefits for the people, and so that Allah may make evident those who support Him and His messengers unseen. Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might." (al-Hadid/57: 25)

According to Mahmud Syaltut, Allah SWT mentioning iron in the context of establishing justice contains a strong and clear indication that the establishment and implementation of justice is a divine decree that must be carried out. Those who implement it can use the power that God permits, such as with iron tools (weapons) that have tremendous power.

As for the types of justice presented by Islam, among others, are as follows:

First: Justice in Belief

According to the Qur'an, polytheistic belief (*shirk*) is an injustice. As Allah SWT says:

"O my son, do not associate [anything] with Allah. Indeed, association [with Him] is great injustice." (Luqman/31: 13)

To single out God (*Tawhid*) is justice, because He alone is the source of life and existence. He gives blessings, both outwardly and inwardly. All worship, gratitude, and praise are only for Allah SWT. Directing worship and praise to other than Allah is an unjust act or an injustice. Humans have the right to receive mercy and blessings from Allah, therefore humans are obligated to single out Allah in belief and worship.

Second: Justice in the Household

The household is part of society. When the household is prosperous, society will be prosperous, and the state will be strong.

From a good household, good individuals are born. Therefore, Islam establishes regulations in building a household that are quite flexible and perfect. Justice not only underlies formal provisions concerning the rights and obligations of husband and wife, but also justice underlies the relationship of affection with the wife.

Third: Justice in Agreements

In fulfilling the needs of life, every person or nation certainly needs the help of others. Helping and assisting each other in the effort to achieve each other's needs is a characteristic of human life. Islam provides guidance in organizing this life of mutual help. For example, in matters of *muamalah*, such as debt, buying and selling, renting, and so on, with an agreement, Islam commands that the agreement be written.

Allah SWT's saying:

"O you who have believed, when you contract a debt for a specified term, write it down. And let a scribe write [it] between you in justice. ¦ That is more just in the sight of Allah and stronger as evidence and more likely to prevent doubt between you¦." (al-Baqarah/2: 282)

In testimonies that often occur in agreements, Islam also establishes justice. Justice in testimony is to carry out the contents of the testimony honestly without deviation and falsification.

Allah SWT's saying:

"¦And conceal not the testimony, for whoever conceals it - his heart is indeed sinful¦." (al-Baqarah/2: 283)

Allah SWT's saying:

"O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm in justice, witnesses for Allah, even if it be against yourselves or parents and relatives¦." (an-Nisa'/4: 135)

Fourth: Justice in Law

In Islam, all humans are equal before God; there is no difference between white and black people, between the children of kings and the children of the people; all are equal in the treatment of the law. Implementing legal justice is regarded by Islam as fulfilling a trust.

Allah SWT's saying:

"Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due and when you judge between people to judge with justice¦." (an-Nisa'/4: 58)

Hadith of the Prophet SAW:

"Indeed, the destruction of the nations before you was because if a prominent person stole, they would not punish him, but if a weak person stole, they would punish him. By Allah, if Fatimah bint Muhammad stole, I would surely cut off her hand." (Narrated by Muslim)

In addition to being just, Allah SWT also commands to do *ihsan*, such as repaying the kindness of others with better/greater kindness or forgiving others.

Allah's saying:

"And when you are greeted with a greeting, greet [in return] with one better than it or [at least] return it [in a like manner]. Indeed, Allah is ever, over all things, an Accountant." (an-Nisa'/4: 86)

Al-Ihsan is divided into three categories:

1. Al-Ihsan in worship: you worship Allah as if you see Him. If you do not see Him, indeed Allah sees you.

Hadith of the Prophet Muhammad SAW:

"*Ihsan* is that you worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then He sees you." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)

2. Al-Ihsan in retribution and sanctions with balance, and perfecting rights in murder and injury with *qisas*.

3. Al-Ihsan in fulfilling rights or debts by paying them without delay, or with an unconditional addition.

The highest level of *al-ihsan* is doing good to those who are wrong. It is narrated that Isa AS once said, "Indeed, *al-ihsan* is that you do good to those who are wrong against you. It is not *al-ihsan* if you do good to those who have done good to you."

Allah SWT also commands in this verse to give charity to relatives for their needs. Giving charity to relatives is actually included in the recognition of doing justice and *al-ihsan*. However, it is mentioned specifically to give the understanding that the matter of providing assistance to relatives should be considered and prioritized.

After explaining the three matters commanded to mankind, Allah SWT continues by explaining three more matters that must be abandoned.

First: Forbidding indecency (*fahisyah*), which are actions based on satisfying lusts, such as adultery, intoxicating drinks, and stealing.

Second: Forbidding evil (*mungkar*), which are bad deeds that are contrary to sound reason, such as killing and robbing the rights of others.

Third: Forbidding arbitrary hostility towards others.

Thus, in this verse, Allah SWT commands three things that must be done, namely being just, *al-ihsan*, and strengthening brotherhood. Allah also forbids three things, namely committing indecency, evil, and hostility.

All of that is a lesson to humans that will bring them to happiness in this world and the hereafter, so they should practice it.
text.91:
In this verse, Allah swt commands the Muslims to fulfill their covenant with Allah if they have already made that covenant. According to Ibn Jarir, these verses were revealed concerning the bai'at (pledge of allegiance) to the Prophet Muhammad saw made by those who had newly entered Islam. They were commanded to fulfill the pledge of allegiance that they had affirmed with an oath, and to prevent them from breaking it. The small number of Muslims should not encourage them to break that bai'at after seeing the large number of polytheists.

According to this verse, all binding agreements made willingly must be fulfilled, whether the agreement is between Muslims or with those outside of Islam. Allah swt forbids Muslims from violating oaths spoken using the name of Allah, because in such an oath, Allah has been placed as a witness. Allah will reward those who fulfill what they have spoken with an oath or retaliate with torment for those who betray that oath. Indeed, Allah knows all the deeds of mankind. He knows all the agreements that they strengthen with oaths, and He also knows how they fulfill those promises and oaths.
text.92:
In this verse, Allah likens those who break covenants and oaths to a woman who unravels the thread that has been strongly spun, turning it back into scattered pieces. This is a depiction of the behavior of madmen and fools.

Violation of a *bai'at* (pledge of allegiance) or oath means using the oath as a tool to deceive fellow human beings. Because if one group or individual makes an agreement with another group that is larger and stronger than them to reassure them, and then, if given the opportunity, they betray that agreement, then such behavior is considered a form of deception.

Allah swt forbids such behavior because it is considered foolish and insane, even if they are from a small group facing a large group. It is even more forbidden if a large group cancels an agreement with a smaller group.

It is narrated that Mu'awiyah, the first caliph of the Umayyad Dynasty, once made a peace treaty with the Roman Emperor for a certain period. Towards the end of that peace treaty, Mu'awiyah brought his troops to the border with the intention of attacking as soon as the treaty expired. Then a companion named Amr bin Anbasah said to him, "Allahu Akbar, O Mu'awiyah, fulfill the promise, do not betray, I once heard the Messenger saw say:

Whoever has a treaty period between him and another group, then he should never break that treaty until its time is up. (Narrated by Imam Ahmad)

After Mu'awiyah heard his friend's warning, he returned and took his troops back. Thus, Islam establishes provisions in the social interaction between people to test among them who is the strongest in adhering to the agreements they have made themselves, whether that agreement is to Allah and His Messenger, such as *bai'at*, or to fellow human beings. On the Day of Judgment, it will be clear: which is right and which is wrong, and which is honest and which is treacherous. All disputes will be clarified, and each will receive a reward from Allah swt.
text.93:
Then, in this verse, Allah SWT states that if He willed, He would certainly be able to unite mankind into one religion in accordance with human nature, and eliminate the ability to choose and deliberate on what is done. Thus, humans would live like ants or bees, or live like angels created like robots, full of obedience to Allah, not deviating in the slightest from the correct provisions, or straying onto the wrong path. However, Allah SWT did not will this in creating mankind. Allah created mankind by bestowing upon them the ability to choose and strive with full consideration. This power of consideration has been given to humans since eternity. Reward and punishment are closely related to human choices and considerations. Each is held accountable for all actions resulting from their considerations and choices. As Allah says:

"And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives. And that his effort is going to be seen." (an-Najm/53: 39-40)
text.94:
Allah SWT reaffirms to Muslims His prohibition against using oaths as a tool for deception among themselves. After Allah SWT forbade breaking agreements and oaths in general, in this verse, Allah SWT specifically affirms the prohibition against breaking the agreements that the Muslims had made with the Prophet Muhammad SAW while he was still in Mecca, before the Hijrah to Medina.

Allah SWT does not justify making agreements only to deceive people. This prohibition arose because of the desire of some Muslims to break their bai'at (pledge of allegiance) which had been strengthened by oaths. If they did such a thing, it would mean that their feet would slip after having stood on a firm footing.

They will experience suffering because of their actions in making oaths a tool of deception among people. There are three punishments for those who violate this if they commit such an act.

First: They become further away from the truth and guidance of Allah SWT, even though they are already within the line of truth.

Second: They set an example in deviating from the path of Allah. With that bad habit, they deserve punishment in this world, such as murder, arrest, robbery, and expulsion from their homeland.

Third: They will be punished in the Hereafter as a reward for their audacity in turning away from the truth. They will be included in the group of people who are miserable and misguided.
text.95:
In this verse, Allah reaffirms His prohibition against breaking oaths of allegiance (bai'at) by stating that such an act is tantamount to exchanging a covenant with Allah for a cheap price. For example, to obtain worldly gains and a small amount of wealth, they break an agreement they themselves made. This warning from Allah relates to the situation of the people of Mecca who had pledged bai'at to the Prophet (saw) and then intended to break that bai'at after seeing the strength of the Quraysh and their persecution of Muslims.

Furthermore, the Quraysh promised the Muslims that they would give them something if they were willing to return to the religion of polytheism. Therefore, Allah warns them with this verse and prevents them from breaking their bai'at to the Prophet, just to obtain worldly wealth. Because what is with Allah, such as rewards in the Hereafter and the religion brought by the Prophet (saw) for worldly life, is far better than what is promised by the polytheistic leaders. If they used their intellect and reflected on these matters, they would certainly be more inclined to remain loyal to the Prophet (saw) and reject the invitations of the polytheistic leaders.
text.96:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that everything possessed and received by humans, in the form of worldly material possessions, is limited and has an end. Meanwhile, what is with Allah, in the form of rewards and recompense in Paradise, is limitless, unceasing, and even everlasting. Therefore, to those who believe, are patient in facing the tasks of religion, and steadfast in facing suffering, Allah will surely give a reward greater than what they have done. The Lord highlights the characteristic of patience or steadfastness because that characteristic is the foundation of all good deeds.

Allah's word:

"So whatever thing you have been given - it is but [for] enjoyment of the worldly life. But what is with Allah is better and more lasting for those who have believed and upon their Lord rely." (ash-Shura/42: 36)

Allah's word also:

"Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope." (al-Kahf/18: 46)
text.97:
Then, in this verse, Allah SWT promises that He will indeed grant a happy and prosperous life in this world to His servants, both male and female, who perform righteous deeds, which are all deeds that conform to the guidance of the Al-Qur'an and the Sunnah of the Messenger, while their hearts are filled with faith.

The Messenger of Allah said:

From 'Abdullah bin 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah SAW said, "Successful is the one who embraces Islam, is given sufficient sustenance, and is content with what Allah has given him." (Narrated by Ahmad)

This happy and prosperous life in this world is a life in which the human soul obtains tranquility and peace because it feels the sweetness of faith and the pleasure of conviction. His soul is filled with longing for Allah's promise, but is willing and sincere in accepting destiny. His soul is free from the bondage of worldly things, and is only focused on the One God, and receives an abundance of light from Him.

His soul is always satisfied with everything that is destined for him, because he knows that the sustenance he receives is the result of Allah SWT's decree. As for the Hereafter, he will receive a great and the best reward from Allah because of the wisdom and righteous deeds he has done, and the pure faith that fills his soul.
text.98:
Then, in this verse, Allah SWT teaches the etiquette of reciting the Qur'an so that in reading and understanding it, one is far from the disturbances of Satan. The Qur'an guides mankind to the path of happiness, and determines which righteous deeds are beneficial for human life and which deeds lead to the path of misery. However, the guidance of the Qur'an can only be understood and comprehended correctly if the reader's mind is free from the temptations of Satan.

Allah SWT says:

"Indeed, those who fear Allah - when an impulse touches them from Satan, they remember [Him] and at once they have insight." (al-A'raf/7: 201)

And Allah says:

"Indeed, Satan is an enemy to you, so take him as an enemy. He only invites his party to be among the companions of the Blaze." (Fathir/35: 6)

If even the Messenger of Allah was commanded by Allah to seek refuge in Him when about to recite the Qur'an, even though he was declared protected, what about humans who are not messengers? Indeed, humans are weak and easily influenced by Satan in understanding the Qur'an. Reciting the Qur'an is a human effort to draw closer to Allah. Satan strives hard to distance humans from Allah's guidance in various ways. Therefore, Allah commands us to seek His help with the words:

"I seek refuge in Allah from Satan, the outcast."
text.99: In this verse, Allah swt explains that Satan has no influence over those who believe, those who submit themselves to Allah swt, and those who are patient and trustingly endure suffering in the struggle to uphold religion. They are able to resist Satan's temptations and refuse to follow in his footsteps and become his followers. Thanks to the light of faith in their hearts, they can recognize and overcome Satan's deceptions. Satan only has influence over those who have already submitted to his dominion, those who regard Satan as a leader, then love him, follow him, and obey all his commands. Because of Satan's deceptions and temptations, they ultimately associate partners with God or worship Satan alongside worshiping Allah swt.
text.100: In this verse, Allah swt explains that Satan has no influence over those who believe, those who submit themselves to Allah swt, and those who are patient and rely on Him in enduring suffering in the struggle to uphold religion. They are able to resist Satan's temptations and refuse to follow his footsteps and become his followers. Thanks to the light of faith in their hearts, they can recognize and overcome Satan's deceptions. Satan only has influence over those who have already submitted to his dominion, those who regard Satan as a leader, then love him, follow him, and obey all his commands. Because of Satan's deceptions and temptations, they ultimately associate partners with God or worship Satan alongside worshiping Allah swt.
text.101:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah has replaced a verse in the Al-Qur'an with another verse. This replacement is intended for the benefit of mankind, because only Allah knows which law is more suitable for a particular time for a particular people.

The polytheists reproached the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) because, according to them, the Prophet at one time commanded something, and at another time forbade it. They said that the Messenger liked to fabricate things. This attitude arose because they did not know the wisdom contained in the replacement of the verse.

The replacement of verses or laws of the Al-Qur'an only occurs in a few verses, for example, in the matter of changing the customs of a people. If this change were made all at once, it would cause upheaval among them. It is very wise in building change in a society to always pay attention to the psychological aspects of that society. But for those whose hearts are closed by arrogance and hostility towards the Messenger, the replacement of verses that support and contain wisdom is used as a source of slander against him. (See Tafsir al-Baqarah/2: 106).
text.102:
In this verse, Allah SWT commands the Messenger SAW to explain to the polytheists that these verses are not his fabrication, but were revealed by the angel Jibril A.S. from Allah Rabbul 'Alamin, group by group with perfect wisdom, according to the development of society and its needs. Allah also presents His attribute of *rububiyah* and connects it to the Prophet Muhammad SAW (*Rabbika* = Your Lord), to provide understanding that Allah's guidance to the Messenger is gradual in order to achieve perfection. Allah will bestow the radiance of that attribute of *rububiyah* upon His Prophet.

The Qur'an was revealed gradually to the Messenger to strengthen the faith of those who believe, to provide guidance for them in the oneness of Allah SWT, and to be a guide in seeking a happy life in this world and the hereafter.

The Qur'an also explains to the believers that they will receive paradise in the hereafter as a reward for their good deeds in this world.
text.103:
Allah SWT explains that the polytheists of Mecca accused the Prophet Muhammad SAW of receiving lessons of the Qur'an from someone. According to them, that person was a foreign man, not an Arab, who always taught old books in their midst. But that accusation was not true because the Qur'an is composed in beautiful and concise Arabic, how could a foreigner create it? To what extent could a non-Quraysh Arab feel the beauty of the Arabic language and then compose it in a beautiful and concise way like the Qur'an? Moreover, if it is said that that person became the Prophet's teacher. Regarding who that foreigner was, various narrations explain it. Among them, some say that the foreigner was a Roman slave who was a Christian, who was kept by Bani Hadrami. Nevertheless, from the various narrations, none can be relied upon.

It is highly likely that the accusation was just a trick of the polytheists who deliberately hurled it at the Prophet SAW and the Muslims. The Quraysh leaders who traded to Syam (Syria) had more or less heard the contents of the Torah and the Gospel because of their relationship with the People of the Book. Because the Qur'an contains the contents of the Torah, they then thought that there must be a foreign person ('ajam) who was a Christian teaching the contents of the Qur'an to the Prophet.
text.104:
