In this verse, Allah swt affirms that without faith in Allah swt and the Qur'an as His revelation, a person will not receive guidance to the true reality that frees them from torment. Those who say that the Qur'an is man-made or ancient fables are certainly far from Allah's guidance and will not be able to find the path of truth.

The Qur'an, which should have been their guide, is abandoned, causing them to become misguided. Therefore, they easily fall into evil, so their souls become dirty and covered by the stains of sin. They will surely be miserable and tormented in this world and in the hereafter.
text.105: This verse refutes the accusations of the disbelievers who said that the Qur'an was Muhammad's creation. Indeed, those who fabricate lies are not the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him), but those who do not believe in the verses of Allah, both the *kauniyah* verses that explain the oneness and power of Allah found in this universe, and the *qur'aniyah* verses that provide guidance in this life. So, in reality, they are the liars, not the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him), because he is the most honest person, perfect in his knowledge and deeds, strong in his faith, and most trustworthy. Because of his honesty and purity of soul, he was given the name *al-Amin* (the trustworthy).
text.106:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the severe threat against riddah (apostasy), which is returning to disbelief after having faith, and preferring error over His guidance (hidayah). They will receive the wrath and punishment of Allah, except in conditions of compulsion. For example, they declare apostasy with their tongue because their life is threatened, but their hearts remain full of faith. There is no sin or legal claim against them, as long as they remain believers.

The Messenger of Allah said:

"My ummah will not be held accountable for mistakes, forgetfulness, and what they are forced to do." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani from Thawban)
text.107:
In this verse, the reasons for Allah's wrath upon those who truly revert to disbelief after having believed are explained. They are considered to prioritize worldly life over the afterlife, with all the pleasures promised by Allah to those who truly believe and whose faith has been tested with various trials and tribulations in the world. Allah will not grant His guidance to those who apostatize, not due to compulsion. In the Hereafter, they will receive a painful torment.

Allah will not grant *taufik* to those who deny His verses, and those who have deliberately removed the willingness of their souls to accept goodness and then exchanged it for sin and evil.
text.108:
Allah SWT explains another punishment for apostates in this verse, which is that Allah SWT seals their hearts (souls), views, and sight. Their hearts are sealed due to their hardness and disbelief, so they cannot be opened to understand and respond to the signs of Allah's existence. Their views and sight are sealed because the understanding and impression of what they hear and see do not reach their hearts.

The radiance of Divine light and knowledge cannot penetrate and illuminate their hearts towards the Divine path. Their inner selves are also unable to absorb scientific facts as signs of Allah SWT's oneness and greatness. Such people are described by Allah SWT as being like animals, even worse.

Allah SWT says:

"And whoever of you reverts from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds will be lost in this world and the Hereafter, and they are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 217)

A further punishment for those who apostatize is making them oblivious to the essence of truth. They have no attention whatsoever to their surroundings, so they become passive (jumud) and isolated.

The punishment for a Muslim who consciously apostatizes from Islam is the death penalty, as carried out by Ali RA and Mu'adh bin Jabal against apostates in their time, based on the narration of Imam Ahmad. Both companions adhered to the saying of the Prophet:

"Whoever changes his religion (Islam), kill him." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Abbas)
text.109:
In this verse, Allah SWT affirms that those who apostatize are truly the losers in the hereafter because they have defiled their own souls and plunged themselves into the abyss of hellfire. They receive the following:

1.  The wrath of Allah.

2.  A painful torment.

3.  They do not receive guidance from Allah.

4.  Their hearts, hearing, and sight are sealed.

5.  On the Day of Judgment, they will be the losers.

They lose the worldly pleasures they pursued by pouring out their energy and spending their lives. In the hereafter, they receive nothing but suffering. They do not realize that the main capital for living in this world is life itself. If that capital is not used for essential purposes, then surely that capital will be wasted in vain.
text.110:
Allah explains the situation of the Muslims in Mecca who were under great pressure, so much so that they did not dare to show their Islam. Whenever they were seen performing worship, they were forced and tortured to return to the religion of their ancestors, which was the religion of shirk, as experienced by 'Ammar bin Yasir, Khabbab, and others. Because of the humiliation and threats of persecution, they then pretended to return to the religion of shirk.

They followed the will of the Quraysh under the threat of torture. When they had the opportunity to migrate and leave the city of Mecca, they left to migrate. With sincerity, they parted with their relatives, possessions, and homeland only to seek the pleasure of Allah. They faced various kinds of suffering and difficulties in that migration, both on the journey and upon arrival at their destination. They faced all that suffering and difficulty with patience and reliance (tawakal) on Allah.

Their destination was the land of Habashah (Ethiopia), which was very far from Mecca. They traveled that long distance on foot. When they arrived at their destination, they had to struggle again to maintain their faith while preaching (da'wah).

After they experienced those trials and sufferings, Allah forgave the mistakes they made under the threat of torture, such as uttering words of disbelief (kufr) again. Allah SWT bestowed His mercy and compassion by giving them a great reward in the Hereafter.
text.111:
On the Day of Reckoning, every person will be held accountable for every deed they committed during their life in the world, whether it be good or evil. Allah SWT says:

(Remember) the Day when every soul will find present [before it] what it has done of good and what it has done of evil. (Ali 'Imran/3: 30)

No one on that day can defend another. Each person will bear their own burden and will not bear the sins of others. Allah SWT says:

And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. (Fathir/35: 18)

All deeds, whether good or evil, will be rewarded on that day, and no one will be wronged. Each person will fully receive the recompense for every deed they committed. Those who do good will be perfectly rewarded for their good deeds, and those who commit sins will be perfectly punished for their sinful actions. Allah SWT says:

And fear a Day when you will be returned to Allah. Then every soul will be compensated for what it earned, and they will not be treated unjustly. (al-Baqarah/2: 281)
text.112:
In the history of past communities, there are many examples that should serve as lessons for humanity thereafter. One community that lived in a country, initially lived happily both physically and spiritually, safely, and peacefully. They were protected from enemy threats and far from the disaster of famine and misery. Allah bestowed sustenance upon them, both sustenance found in their own country and sustenance that came from abroad. All of this made them live prosperously and peacefully. However, all of Allah's abundant blessings were not appreciated; instead, they became disbelievers and ungrateful to Him. Their lives were no longer bound by moral and religious norms. They were intoxicated with wealth and luxury, forgetting their responsibilities to their nation and country. Therefore, Allah sent down punishment in the form of famine and anxiety that enveloped their lives. That was their recompense.

Allah SWT says:

"Have you not seen those who have exchanged the favor of Allah for disbelief and settled their people [in] the home of ruin? [It is] Hell, which they will [enter to] burn, and wretched is the destination." (Ibrahim/14: 28-29)

They should have been grateful for all those great blessings, and not done the opposite. Because of their disbelief, Allah exchanged the atmosphere of safety, peace, and prosperity for an atmosphere of famine and fear. Similarly, was the condition of the city of Mecca and its inhabitants. The city of Mecca, due to its strategic location in the middle of the Arabian Peninsula, had become a trade route city between the northern and southern parts. Three famous markets were located around it, namely: Ukaz Market near Taif Market, Majannah near Mecca, and dzulmajaz near Arafah. These markets were crowded with visitors in the months of Zulkaidah and Zulhijah by Arabs from all tribes. In addition to those months for performing the Hajj pilgrimage at the Kaaba, they also held various activities, such as trading and reciting beautiful poems. Mecca, even before Islam, was already a bustling city. Many people who visited Mecca brought sustenance and prosperity. The Qur'an narrates the location of Mecca, which is between two large countries, namely Syam and Yemen.

Allah SWT says:

"There was for [the tribe of] Saba' in their dwelling place a sign: two gardens on the right and on the left. [They were told], "Eat from the provision of your Lord and be grateful to Him. A good land [it is], and a forgiving Lord." But they turned away [from Allah], so We sent upon them the flood of the dam, and We replaced their two gardens with gardens of bitter fruit, tamarisks and a few lote trees." (Saba'/34: 15-16)

That the city of Mecca is a safe and peaceful land is stated by Allah in the Qur'an with His words:

"And they say, "If we were to follow the guidance with you, we would be removed from our land." Have We not established for them a safe sanctuary to which are brought fruits of all kinds as provision from Us? But most of them do not know." (al-Qasas/28: 57)
text.113:
Among their actions that demonstrate ingratitude for blessings is rejecting and opposing the Messenger, as explained by Allah in this verse. When the Messenger came to them providing teachings and guidance, they rejected and opposed him, even though they knew the Messenger's origins, character, and interactions. They also understood that the teachings taught by the Messenger were true, but driven by self-interest and baseless hatred, they rejected and opposed him. According to Allah's sunnah, every people to whom a Messenger has come, but they reject and oppose him, will be afflicted with punishment.

Allah SWT says:

"And We would never punish [a people] until We had sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15)

The polytheists of Mecca were also not spared from Allah's punishment as a result of their actions of opposing Prophet Muhammad SAW, just like the previous peoples. They experienced suffering and misery due to famine for many years. Allah sent down punishment upon them because of the Prophet Muhammad SAW's supplication after he had suffered much hardship. The Prophet SAW prayed:

"O Allah, inflict Your punishment severely upon the tribe of Mudhar (the polytheists of Quraysh), and make the punishment upon them years like the years of famine in the time of Prophet Yusuf AS." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn Mas'ud)

For a year, the polytheists of Mecca suffered from famine that depleted their wealth, so that they were forced to eat camel skin, dogs, carrion, and burnt bones. Previously, they always obtained abundant sustenance and food that came from all directions. However, everything had changed so that they had to live in deprivation. Likewise, their lives, which were originally safe and peaceful, turned into hostility and fear of the Messenger SAW and his companions. This fear arose after the Messenger and his companions migrated to Medina. They felt anxious about the strength of the Islamic forces, which at any time could ambush their trade caravans or livestock. That was Allah's punishment that was sent down upon them, namely famine and fear that enveloped their lives due to their ingratitude for Allah's blessings. They were the wrongdoers, committing injustice, and unwilling to be grateful for Allah's blessings. Muhammad SAW, along with his companions and followers, experienced a change in life. They were formerly in fear, but changed to peace and tranquility, and from hardship changed to prosperity and happiness. They eventually became the leaders of mankind and rulers of the world.
text.114:
In this verse, Allah commands the Muslims to eat lawful and good food from the sustenance that Allah SWT has given them, whether the food comes from animals or plants. Lawful food is food and drink that is permitted by religion to be eaten and drunk. Good food is food and drink that is permitted to be eaten or drunk by health standards, including nutritious, delicious, and healthy food. It is this lawful and good food that Allah has commanded to be eaten and drunk. Food that is permitted by health science is abundant, and is fundamentally permissible to be eaten and drunk.

Allah SWT says:

"O you who have believed, eat from the good things which We have provided for you..." (al-Baqarah/2: 172)

Allah SWT says:

"They ask you, [O Muhammad], what has been made lawful for them. Say, "Lawful for you are [all] good foods and [game caught by] what you have trained of hunting animals which you train according to what Allah has taught you..." (al-Ma'idah/5: 4)

Good food and drink are not forbidden to eat, unless Allah SWT or His Messenger forbids it.

Allah SWT says:

"O you who have believed, do not prohibit the good things which Allah has made lawful to you and do not transgress. Indeed, Allah does not like transgressors." (al-Ma'idah/5: 87)

Food that is spread on the face of the earth from the types of animals and plants is a great blessing from Allah SWT. Humans should be grateful for it by saying "Alhamdulillah" and utilizing it according to the guidance of Allah and His Messenger, such as eating or trading it. The Prophet SAW said:

"Indeed, Allah is truly pleased with a servant who says "Alhamdulillah"." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani from al-Aswad bin Sari')

Included in the meaning of being grateful is preserving and developing sources of food so that they do not become extinct from the face of the earth and to meet the nutritional needs of human beings. In preserving and developing animals or plants, Muslims should submit to Allah's laws that apply, for example, regarding the provisions of zakat and its social function.

Being grateful for Allah's blessings means uttering words of gratitude when utilizing, preserving, and developing them based on Allah's guidance, because He is the One who gives the grace and blessings. Every believer should obey Allah's provisions and commands, and avoid His prohibitions if they truly believe in Him.
text.115:
In this verse, Allah explains the foods that are forbidden for Muslims. The foods forbidden in this verse are carrion, blood, pork, and animals slaughtered in the name of idols or anything other than the name of Allah. The prohibition of these foods is solely the right and wisdom of Allah swt in guiding His servants. As Allah says:

Indeed, Allah decrees what He intends. (al-Ma'idah/5: 1)

Among the wisdom or purpose of the prohibition of these foods, some are accessible to reason (ta'aqquli), and some are not accessible to reason (ta'abbudi). Every Muslim is obligated to obey Allah's prohibitions with sincerity and full faith.

Carrion is an animal that dies naturally due to natural causes, or dies because it was not slaughtered according to Islamic rules. Included in the meaning of carrion here are animals that die by strangulation, die by being squeezed (beaten), die by falling, being gored, and being eaten by wild animals.

Allah swt says:

Forbidden to you are dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah, and [those animals] killed by strangling or by a violent blow or by a fall or by being gored or what wild animals have eaten, except what you [are able to] slaughter [before its death], and those which are sacrificed on stone altars. (al-Ma'idah/5: 3)

All carrion is forbidden to eat except for fish carrion, as Allah swt says:

Lawful for you is game from the sea and its food as provision for yourselves and travelers. (al-Ma'idah/5: 96)

The blood that is forbidden is flowing blood or congealed blood (marus). The liver and kidneys are not considered forbidden blood to eat. Hadith of the Prophet saw:

Two kinds of carrion and blood have been made lawful for us. The two carrion are fish and locusts, and the two bloods are liver and spleen. (Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Majah from Ibn 'Umar)

Included in the meaning of pork is fat, bones and all its parts, as well as all products made from pork elements and its derivatives. Pigs are among the dirtiest livestock in terms of their lifestyle and diet. Their meat contains tapeworm seeds that cause many diseases in the human body.

Allah forbids animals that are slaughtered while intentionally mentioning names other than Allah, such as the names of statues, jinn, gods, saints, and so on. The prohibition aims to prevent things that tend towards shirk.

An-Nawawi in the book Syarah Muslim says that if the intention of the slaughterer in mentioning names other than Allah is to magnify that name and intend it as worship to him, then that action is considered shirk. If the slaughterer acts in this way, he can be judged to have left the religion (murtad). This is An-Nawawi's explanation when giving an explanation of the Hadith of the Prophet saw:

Allah curses those who slaughter animals for other than Allah. (Narrated by Muslim from Ali bin Abi thalib)

The religion of Islam is a religion that always provides spaciousness for its adherents. There are no things in Islam that are troublesome and complicate matters. Therefore, all forbidden foods may be eaten if a person is in a state of compulsion or emergency. For example, a hunter in the middle of the forest in a state of empty stomach, if left alone, can destroy himself, while other food is not available, he is allowed to eat forbidden food to overcome his condition, provided that it is not driven by a desire to eat the forbidden food itself. If he eats more than is necessary, it is not justified. Because, it can create new difficulties related to food that contains the disease. Indeed, Allah swt forgives what His servants do in times of difficulty, and has mercy on them by giving them leniency in their lives in this world.
text.116:
In this verse, Allah swt forbids Muslims from declaring foods forbidden or permissible according to their desires and whims, as the polytheists did. They had the habit of declaring animals forbidden or permissible based solely on names and terms they themselves established for those animals, for example: bahirah, sa'ibah, wasilah, and ham, as Allah swt says:

"Allah has not appointed [such innovations as] bahirah or sa'ibah or wasilah or ham. But those who disbelieve invent falsehood about Allah, and most of them do not reason." (al-Ma'idah/5: 103)

In determining the permissibility or prohibition of a food or drink, it must be based on *dalil syara* (legal evidence) sourced from the Al-Qur'an and Sunnah. Establishing a ruling without *dalil syara* is not permissible. This includes acts of innovation and fabricating lies against Allah.

In the Al-Qur'an, the words of the polytheists are mentioned regarding the provisions for the offspring still in the womb of its mother. Allah swt says:

"And they say, "What is in the bellies of these animals is exclusively for our males and forbidden to our females." (al-An'am/6: 139)

Because it has very bad consequences for religious life, Allah gives a stern warning to those who fabricate lies against Allah. Allah affirms that those who do so will not achieve success in their lives, either in this world or in the Hereafter. In this world, those who like to create laws without valid evidence will be condemned and abandoned by society. Their lies will be known by the community, and they will become the target of ridicule and humiliation.

In Tafsir Ibn Kathir, it is revealed that included in the meaning of this verse is anyone who creates *bid'ah* (religious innovation) that has no basis in *syara*, or makes permissible something that Allah has forbidden or forbids something that Allah has made permissible, solely based on their own thoughts and tastes.
text.117:
Allah reaffirms that those who fabricate stipulations and laws that have absolutely no basis in the Book of Allah and His Messenger, but are solely based on their desires, will certainly not achieve success in this world or the Hereafter. If there is any benefit from such behavior, then the benefit is very little compared to the losses and dangers resulting from that action.

Throughout history, many tragic events have occurred as a result of religious opinions that do not originate from the Holy Book. These opinions are sometimes created solely to fulfill the desires and interests of rulers who use religion as a tool to strengthen their power and reinforce their desires. What is permissible is forbidden, and what is forbidden is made permissible by those who seek worldly gain. They forget that worldly pleasures are few and limited to their short lifespan. But in the eternal life of the Hereafter, they will receive punishment from Allah because of the audacity of their tongues when lying to Allah. They have committed a crime, defiling their own souls with sin and lies against God. Even others fall into sin and error because of their fatwas that permit what is forbidden or forbid what is permissible. Sins will accumulate on their shoulders because they desire small worldly gains.
text.118:
In this verse, Allah swt reminds us of what was forbidden to the Jews. The things that are halal and haram in the Jewish religion are actually not the same as what is forbidden or made halal by the polytheists. This shows that the determination of halal and haram by the polytheists regarding their livestock does not originate from the laws of previous religions. Some foods have been forbidden by Allah to the Jews, as explained in Allah's word:

And to those who are Jews, We prohibited every animal with undivided hoof, and We forbade them the fat of cows and sheep, except what adheres to their backs or the entrails or what is mixed with bone. Thus We punished them for their wrongdoing. And indeed, We are truthful. (al-An'am/6: 146)

Allah forbade the meat and fat of specific livestock to the Jews as a punishment for their acts of oppression, such as killing prophets, consuming riba (interest), and acquiring wealth in unlawful ways.

Allah swt says:

Because of the wrongdoing of the Jews, We made unlawful for them [certain] good foods which had been lawful to them, and for their hindering many from the way of Allah. (an-Nisa'/4: 160)

From this verse, we can understand the clear difference between the reason Allah forbade certain types of food to the Jews and the reason applied to Muslims. For Muslims, Allah swt does not forbid foods except because there is a harm in that food that could endanger them. Whereas for the Jews, Allah forbade the good foods as a punishment for them.

Therefore, the opinion that the Children of Israel themselves forbade the food to themselves is not correct. All food, before the Torah was revealed to them, was halal, except for the food that Prophet Yaqub (Israel) himself forbade for himself. According to a narration, the food forbidden by Prophet Yaqub was camel meat and milk. He did so to restrain his desires in an effort to purify his soul and to draw closer to Allah.

Allah swt says:

All food was lawful to the Children of Israel except what Israel had made unlawful to himself before the Torah was revealed. (Ali 'Imran/3: 93)

As for foods such as the meat of animals with undivided hooves, and the fat of cows and sheep, they were forbidden to all the Children of Israel at the time the Torah was revealed as a punishment to them.
text.119:
Then, Allah explains the greatness of His mercy and compassion towards His servants by granting forgiveness to those who commit evil in general, whether the evil is in the form of disrespect towards Allah or other acts of evil and disobedience. However, Allah SWT links several conditions to obtaining His love and forgiveness, such as:

First: Those who commit evil due to ignorance or lack of knowledge of religious laws. He does not know that what he is doing violates religious commands and harms himself.

Second: A deep sense of regret arises within him after committing the evil, then he utters istighfar and immediately repents to Allah SWT. Repentance should not be delayed after he realizes his mistake, because doing so damages his faith and soul.

Allah SWT says:

"Allah accepts the repentance of those who do evil in ignorance and then repent soon after. It is they to whom Allah will turn in forgiveness, and Allah is ever Knowing and Wise." (an-Nisa'/4: 17)

Third: Performing righteous deeds and avoiding Allah's prohibitions as evidence of his regret. With a strong intention and a steadfast heart, he promises not to repeat the evil he has committed and is determined to obey Allah SWT.

Allah SWT says:

"And whoever repents and does righteousness does indeed turn to Allah with [due] repentance." (al-Furqan/25: 71)
text.120:
In this verse, Allah swt praises His servant, Ibrahim a.s., as His messenger and khalil (intimate friend). He was the imam of the *hunafa* (those inclined to truth) or the leader of those who love truth and the father of the prophets. Allah swt states in this verse *ummah* which means a leader who is an example. According to 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud, *ummah* means a teacher of wisdom. While according to Ibn Umar, *ummah* means one who teaches people about their religion.

Such a title indicates that Prophet Ibrahim possessed several noble qualities. According to this verse, his qualities are as follows:

1.  He is truly the only Imam. Ibn 'Abbas r.a. said, "Indeed, he possesses virtues equal to the virtues possessed by a whole nation." He is the leader of those who believe in the Oneness of God. He is the one who destroyed idols, opposed the disbelievers, and sought the truth of Allah the Creator through His signs in the horizons.

2.  He is one who is obedient and submissive to Allah, carrying out all commands and abstaining from all prohibitions.

3.  He is one who is far from falsehood, always follows the truth, and does not deviate from it.

4.  He did not follow the polytheistic religion of his people, but was a monotheist from his childhood to his old age. He is the one who dared to speak loudly in front of a polytheistic king, as Allah tells in the Al-Qur'an:

> My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death. (al-Baqarah/2: 258)

He also stated that the worship of idols and stars is wrong with his words quoted in the Al-Qur'an:

> Then when the star set, he said, "I do not like those that set." (al-An'am/6: 76)

With Prophet Ibrahim's personal explanation, the polytheistic Quraysh were cornered because they claimed to adhere to the religion of Prophet Ibrahim, even though in reality, their worship was far from what Prophet Ibrahim exemplified. Likewise, the Jews and Christians who glorified Prophet Ibrahim, turned out to have deviated greatly from the teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism).

Allah's explanation about Ibrahim reveals the falsehood and errors of their beliefs.

Allah swt says:

> Ibrahim was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists. (Ali 'Imran/3: 67)

5.  Prophet Ibrahim a.s. is one who is grateful for the blessings of Allah swt bestowed upon him, as also explained in Allah's word:

> And [of] Ibrahim, who fulfilled [his obligations]? (an-Najm/53: 37)

Meaning that Prophet Ibrahim is one who always carries out all of Allah's commands. Allah's explanation about this trait is a sharp insinuation to the Quraysh because they denied Allah's blessings, so they were punished with hunger and fear.

6.  He is indeed Allah swt's choice for prophethood, as His word:

> And We had already given Abraham his sound judgment before, and We were of him well-Knowing. (al-Anbiya'/21: 51)

7.  That Allah swt guided Ibrahim to the straight path, which is to worship only Him, none is worthy of worship except Him, and there is no partner for Him. Furthermore, Ibrahim taught people the path of *tauhid* and invited people to the religion of Allah.

Allah swt says:

> And remember Our servants, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob - those of enduring strength and [profound religious] vision. Indeed, We chose them for an exclusive [quality]: remembrance of the home [of the Hereafter]. And indeed they are, in Our sight, among the chosen and outstanding. (as-shad/38: 45- 47)

8.  Ibrahim was made by Allah as a beloved prophet of mankind and recognized by all adherents of major religions in the world. Jews, Christians, and Muslims recognize the prophethood of Ibrahim a.s. Even the disbelieving Quraysh were very proud of Prophet Ibrahim's prayer to become a beloved of mankind in the future.

Allah swt says:

> [And he said], "My Lord, grant me wisdom and join me with the righteous. And grant me a reputation of honor among later generations. (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 83-84)

9.  That in the Hereafter he will be included in the ranks of the righteous and occupy a high degree in Paradise, according to his own request.

These are some of the perfect qualities of Prophet Ibrahim's personality. In short, it can be said that he has the qualities of leadership, is obedient (disciplined), has noble character (moralist), is steadfast (consistent) in the truth, is a pure *muwahhid* (monotheist), is grateful and appreciative, is a teacher, and has a fragrant and famous name among mankind, and is among the righteous.

In addition to the general qualities mentioned above, there are still very prominent qualities of Prophet Ibrahim, as explained in the Al-Qur'an, namely:

1.  One who succeeded in finding the Oneness of Allah after a long search process through the signs of Allah's power in the horizons. Therefore, he is titled the Father of *Tauhid* (Monotheism).

2.  One who is very persistent and tenacious in upholding *tauhid* and destroying *shirk* (polytheism), without knowing fatigue and despair.

3.  One who is very resigned and surrenders himself to Allah swt. An example of his perfect surrender to Allah swt is when he received the command to sacrifice his son, Ismail as, he did not hesitate to carry it out.

He is the one who destroyed idols, opposed the disbelievers, and sought the truth of Allah the Creator through His signs in the horizons.

2.  He is one who is obedient and submissive to Allah, carrying out all commands and abstaining from all prohibitions.

3.  He is one who is far from falsehood, always follows the truth, and does not deviate from that truth.

4.  He did not follow the polytheistic religion of his people, but was a monotheist from his childhood to his old age. He is the one who dared to speak loudly in front of a polytheistic king, as Allah tells in the Al-Qur'an:

> My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death. (al-Baqarah/2: 258)

He also stated that the worship of idols and stars is wrong with his words quoted in the Al-Qur'an:

> Then when the star set, he said, "I do not like those that set." (al-An'am/6: 76)

With Prophet Ibrahim's personal explanation, the polytheistic Quraysh were cornered because they claimed to adhere to the religion of Prophet Ibrahim, even though in reality, their worship was far from what Prophet Ibrahim exemplified. Likewise, the Jews and Christians who revered Prophet Ibrahim, turned out to have deviated greatly from the teachings of *tawhid* (monotheism).

Allah's explanation about Ibrahim reveals the falsehood and error of their beliefs.

Allah swt says:

> Ibrahim was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists. (Ali 'Imran/3: 67)

5.  Prophet Ibrahim a.s. is one who is grateful for the blessings of Allah swt bestowed upon him, as also explained in Allah's word:

> And [of] Ibrahim, who fulfilled [his obligations]? (an-Najm/53: 37)

Meaning that Prophet Ibrahim is one who always carries out all of Allah's commands. Allah's explanation of this trait is a sharp insinuation to the Quraysh because they denied Allah's blessings, so they were punished with hunger and fear.

6.  He is indeed Allah swt's choice for prophethood, as His word says:

> And We had already given Abraham his sound judgment before, and We were of him well-Knowing. (al-Anbiya'/21: 51)

7.  That Allah swt guided Ibrahim to the straight path, which is to worship only Him, none is worthy of worship except Him, and there is no partner for Him. Furthermore, Ibrahim taught people the path of *tawhid* and invited people to the religion of Allah.

Allah swt says:

> And remember Our servants, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob - those of enduring strength and [profound religious] vision. Indeed, We chose them for an exclusive [quality]: remembrance of the home [of the Hereafter]. And indeed they are, in Our sight, among the chosen and outstanding. (as-shad/38: 45-47)

8.  Ibrahim was made by Allah as a beloved prophet of mankind and recognized by all adherents of major religions in the world. Jews, Christians, and Muslims acknowledge the prophethood of Ibrahim a.s. Even the disbelievers of Quraysh were very proud of Prophet Ibrahim's prayer to be loved by people in the future.

Allah swt says:

> [And he said], "My Lord, grant me wisdom and join me with the righteous. And grant me a reputation of honor among later generations. (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 83-84)

9.  That he will be included in the ranks of the righteous in the Hereafter and occupy a high degree in Paradise, according to his own request.

These are some of the perfect qualities of Prophet Ibrahim's personality. In short, it can be said that he has the qualities of leadership, is obedient (disciplined), has noble character (moralist), is steadfast (consistent) in truth, is a pure *muwahhid* (monotheist), is grateful and appreciative, is a teacher, and has a fragrant and famous name among mankind, and is among the righteous.

In addition to the general qualities mentioned above, there are still very prominent qualities of Prophet Ibrahim, as explained in the Al-Qur'an, namely:

1.  One who succeeded in finding the Oneness of Allah after a long search process through the signs of Allah's power in the horizons. Therefore, he is titled the Father of *Tawhid* (Monotheism).

2.  One who is very persistent and tenacious in upholding *tawhid* and destroying *shirk* (polytheism), without knowing fatigue and despair.

3.  One who is very submissive and surrenders himself to Allah swt. An example of his perfect surrender to Allah swt is when he received the command to sacrifice his son, Ismail as, he did not hesitate to carry it out.
text.123:
In this verse, the close relationship between the religion of Prophet Ibrahim and the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is emphasized. Allah Almighty says:

"Say, "Indeed, my Lord has guided me to a straight path - a correct religion - the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth. And he was not among those who associate others with Allah." (al-An'am/6: 161)

Among the laws of Prophet Ibrahim that were still valid during the time of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was the practice of circumcision (khitan). Some scholars have stipulated the obligatory nature of circumcision because this law of circumcision was not abrogated by the law of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Allah Almighty says:

"And strive for Allah with the striving due to Him. He has chosen you and has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty. [It is] the religion of your father, Abraham. He [i.e., Allah] named you "Muslims" before [in former scriptures] and in this [revelation] that the Messenger may be a witness over you and you may be witnesses over the people. So establish prayer and give zakah and hold fast to Allah. He is your protector; and excellent is the protector, and excellent is the helper." (al-hajj/22: 78)

Repeatedly in the Qur'an, Allah Almighty affirms that Ibrahim was not a polytheist, unlike the polytheists of Quraysh who claimed to be followers and descendants of Prophet Ibrahim.
text.124:
In this verse, Allah swt condemns the Jews because they disagreed about the status of Saturday. Saturday is the day Allah's wrath fell upon some of the Children of Israel because of their disobedience in violating obligations on that day, as Allah swt explained:

And you certainly knew those among you who transgressed in [the matter of] the Sabbath, and We said to them, "Be apes, despised." (al-Baqarah/2: 65)

Allah swt obligated the Children of Israel to perform worship on Saturday and forbade them and their animals from doing other work. However, some of them did not obey Allah's prohibition and sought ways to justify their actions on that day. Because they made the forbidden permissible, the punishment of God fell upon them by transforming them into apes.

The establishment of Saturday as a holy day for worship is not an inheritance from the law of Prophet Ibrahim, but a provision of the law of Prophet Musa, just as Sunday is for the law of Prophet Isa and Friday for the law of Prophet Muhammad saw.

Allah misguided those before us from Friday, so for the Jews it was Saturday and for the Christians it was Sunday, then Allah came to us and gave us guidance for Friday, then Allah made Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. And thus they will be followers of us on the Day of Resurrection. We are the last of the inhabitants of the world but the first on the Day of Resurrection and judged among them before other creatures are judged. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah and Hudzaifah)

The explanation of these holy days is not a fundamental issue of the law revealed by Allah to the prophets, but rather belongs to the *furuiyah* (branch) issues. Each of them has its own provisions. Prophet Muhammad saw was not commanded to follow the law of Prophet Musa a.s., but he was commanded to follow Prophet Ibrahim a.s.

The disputes among factions within the Jewish religion cannot be resolved among themselves, because they are deeply rooted and widespread. Only Allah swt will determine the decision between them on the Day of Resurrection, concerning the matters they disputed.
text.125:
In this verse, Allah swt gives guidance to His Messenger on how to invite people (da'wah) to the path of Allah. The path of Allah here means the religion of Allah, namely the Islamic sharia revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw.

Allah swt lays the foundations of da'wah as a guide for His people in the future in carrying out the task of da'wah.

First, Allah swt explains to His Messenger that this da'wah is indeed da'wah for the religion of Allah as a path to His pleasure, not da'wah for the personal gain of the dai (the one who preaches) or for his group and people. The Messenger saw was commanded to bring people to the path of Allah and for the religion of Allah alone.

Second, Allah swt explains to the Messenger saw to preach with wisdom (hikmah). Hikmah contains several meanings:

a. Knowledge about the secrets and benefits of everything. With that knowledge, the existence of something can be believed.

b. Precise and correct words that become evidence (arguments) to explain what is right and what is wrong or syubhat (doubtful).

c. Knowing the laws of the Al-Qur'an, understanding the Al-Qur'an, understanding religion, fearing Allah, and being truthful in words and deeds.

The meaning of hikmah that is closest to the truth is the first meaning, namely knowledge about the secrets and benefits of something, meaning that knowledge provides benefits.

Da'wah with hikmah is da'wah with knowledge related to the secrets, benefits, and intentions of divine revelation, in a way that is adapted to the situation and conditions, so that it is easily understood by the people.

Third, Allah swt explains to the Messenger that da'wah should be carried out with good, gentle, and soothing teaching, so that it can be well received.

It is not appropriate if teaching and recitations always cause feelings of anxiety, worry, and fear in the human soul. People who commit sins due to ignorance or lack of knowledge, it is not appropriate if their mistakes are exposed openly in front of other people so that it hurts their feelings.

A sermon or recitation delivered in a gentle language is very good for softening wild hearts and providing more peace than sermons and recitations whose content is threats and terrible curses. However, delivering warnings and threats is permissible if the conditions allow and require it.

To avoid boredom in his recitations, the Messenger saw interspersed and processed enjoyable recitation materials with materials that aroused fear. Thus, there is no boredom caused by recitation descriptions that contain commands and prohibitions without providing recitation materials that broaden the chest or stimulate the heart to perform obedience and avoid prohibitions.

Fourth, Allah swt explains that if there is a debate with the polytheists or the People of the Book, the Messenger should refute them in a good way.

An example of a good debate is the debate of Prophet Ibrahim with his people, inviting them to think to correct their own mistakes, so that they find the truth.

It is not good to provoke opponents in a debate with sharp words, because this creates a heated atmosphere. It is better to create a comfortable and relaxed atmosphere so that the goal in the debate to find the truth can be achieved satisfactorily.

A good debate is a debate that can inhibit the emergence of negative human traits such as arrogance, pride, and trying to maintain self-esteem because these traits are very reprehensible. Opponents in debate should be faced in such a way that they feel that their self-esteem is respected, and the dai shows that the main goal is to find the truth about the religion of Allah swt.

Fifth, the end of all efforts and struggles is faith in Allah swt, because only He bestows faith upon the human soul, not other people or the dai himself. He is the Lord Who knows best who among His servants cannot maintain their human nature (faith in Allah) from misleading influences, until they become misguided, and who among His servants whose human nature remains preserved so that they are open to receiving guidance (hidayah) from Allah swt.
text.126:
Based on the narration of Abu Hurairah, the Prophet (saw) stood before Hamzah when he was martyred in the Battle of Uhud. There was no sight more painful to the Prophet than seeing Hamzah's body mutilated. Then the Prophet said, "May Allah shower His mercy upon you. Indeed, you – as far as I know – were one who loved to maintain kinship ties and did much good. If it were not for the sadness of parting with you, I would have preferred to be with you until the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar) with the spirits. By Allah, I will retaliate with a fitting recompense of seventy people from them in your place." Then Jibril descended, bringing the verses at the end of Surah an-Nahl, "And if you punish [an enemy, O believers], punish with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed. But if you are patient - it is better for those who are patient." At that moment, the Messenger of Allah stood before Hamzah's body.

In this verse, Allah swt affirms to the Muslims, who will inherit the struggle of Prophet Muhammad in spreading the religion of Islam, to make the Prophet's attitude above as their guide in facing the enemy.

The guidance for da'wah (propagation of Islam) given by Allah in the previous verse is guidance in the field of da'wah with the tongue, argument against argument. Da'wah proceeds in a peaceful atmosphere. However, if da'wah receives harsh resistance, for example, the da'i (those who propagate Islam) are tortured or killed, Islam establishes a firm stance to face such a situation while still upholding the truth. Two kinds of paths are explained by Allah in this verse, first: retaliating with a balanced retaliation. Second: accepting the act of hostility with a patient heart and forgiving the mistake if it can have a better influence on the course of da'wah.

According to Ibn Kathir, this verse has the same meaning and purpose as several verses in the Qur'an, namely containing the necessity of justice and the encouragement to do good, such as the word of Allah:

And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it, but whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is [due] from Allah. Indeed, He does not like wrongdoers. (ash-Shura/42: 40)

The word of Allah swt:

...And wounds [inflicted on one another] are [subject to] retaliation. But whoever remits [his right of retaliation] - it is an expiation for him. (al-Ma'idah/5: 45)
text.127:
Allah further emphasizes His command to the Messenger to be patient and steadfast in facing the disturbances of the Quraysh infidels and their obstacles to his da'wah. However, Allah states to the Prophet that this patience is realized inwardly because Allah grants him help and taufik. Patience is a resistance to the symptoms of human emotions and a resistance to turbulent desires. That is the guidance of Allah given to His servants whom He wills.

This statement of Allah heartens the Prophet saw, and the difficulties feel lighter thanks to Allah's grace. The Messenger saw does not need to feel anxious, worried, and saddened by the attitude of his opponents who distance themselves from his call, or their hostile attitude of denying and rejecting the revelation that was sent down to him. Especially if the Messenger saw feels discouraged and hopeless about the denial they commit, such as being accused of being a magician, shaman, poet, and so on, such a thing is even more unjustified by Allah. Actually, all these accusations are intended to prevent others from believing in the Messenger saw. In another verse, Allah forbids the Prophet from being discouraged by the disturbances of the infidels. His word:

"(This is) a Book revealed to you (Muhammad), so let there not be in your breast distress therefrom that you may warn thereby and as a reminder to the believers." (al-A'raf/7: 2)

Although the lessons above are addressed to the Prophet saw, they also apply to his followers.
text.128:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains the reason why the Prophet was commanded to be patient and forbidden to be anxious and discouraged. Allah SWT affirms that He is always with those who are pious and those who do good as their helper. Allah always fulfills their requests, strengthens them, and makes them victorious against the disbelievers.

Those who are pious are always with Allah SWT because they continuously purify themselves to draw closer to Him and eliminate the anxieties that exist in their souls. They are never disappointed if they lose an opportunity, but they are also not happy when they gain an opportunity. Likewise, Allah is always with those who do good, fulfill their obligations to Him, and always obey His commands and avoid His prohibitions. Allah's statement to those who are pious and do ihsan (goodness) in this verse has the same meaning as Allah's statement in His word to the Prophet Musa and Harun a.s.:

He (Allah) said, "Fear not, for I am with you both, hearing and seeing." (Taha/20:46)

It also has the same meaning as Allah's word to the angels:

(Remember) when your Lord revealed to the angels, "Indeed, I am with you, so strengthen those who have believed." (al-Anfal/8:12)
